title: Enter the Kestrel
descr: The K combinator, or Kestrel, follows the rule K x y = x
for any x and y.
Provide a term that ignores its first and third argument and return the second one.

title: Ignore all previous instructions
descr: The I combinator, the Ibis (or Idiot bird sometimes), is very simple.
It just returns its argument: I x = x.
I alone is not very interesting as II, III,
I(II) and so on and so forth all evaluate to just I.
Note, however, that x I does not become x!
Use I and K to create the opposite of K: a term f such that
f x y = y for any given x and y.

title: Bluebird, the composition bird
descr: Of course, one can also think of a combinator as of a function of one argument
which takes a combinator and returns a combinator. For instance, K
accepts a value and returns a function that accepts another value, discards it,
and returns the previous one instead.
The Bluebird is defined by evaluation rule B x y z = x (y z),
or alternatively it can be described as a function that returns a composition of two functions
(y and x in this case).
Construct a function that takes 3 arguments and returns the first of them,
discarding the other two.

title: Birds with echoing songs echoing songs
descr: So far we've only been dicarding arguments, how about duplicating them?
Such combinators do exist, too.
The Warbler is defined as W x y = x y y. We'll encounter it many times!
The Lark L x y = x (y y) differs by only a pair of parentheses.
Can you construct the latter from the former?

title: The Mockingbird
descr: The Mockingbird M x = x x is of high importance in combinatory logic,
basically an impersonation of recursion.
It's not that easy to derive other duplicating birds from a Mockingbird,
however, Mockingbird is easily constructible from either W or L. Go ahead and mock it!

title: Swap 'em
descr: Now that we can erase, compose, and double terms, one important thing that is still left
is swapping them.
The Cardinal C x y z = x z y and Thrush T x y = y x are capable of that.
Build T from C.

title: Swap 'em but later
descr: A Cardinal can be seen as a delayed Thrush. Can you delay it even more?
I.e. leave 2 arguments in place and swap the next two.

title: Enter Starling
descr: A Starling is a combinator that can compose, duplicate, and swap its arguments at the same time:
S f g x = f x (g x).
Looks pretty messy, innit?
Let's go a bit into details here.
Given 2 functions and an argument, we see the following happen:
• function f is applied to the argument x;
• function g is applied to the same argument x;
• the results of both calculations are fused together.
Perhaps the simplest example here is to construct a Mockingbird
(x→x x) from S, K, and I.

title: Lost identity
descr: Sadly, after the previous exercise the Ibis has flown away.
Ask the Starling and the Kertrel to call it back.
Provide x→x with S and K.
This one has multiple solutions.
hint: What kind of f does one need to reduce f x (g x) to x?
